doc.title: Daily Retail and Commerce News (28 August 2025)

passages.text: Carrefour CEO interview, EU/US tariffs, M&S Menswear push

Morning's headlines (full stories below)- Carrefour CEO says French political crisis brings back recession risk.- Carrefour Brasil CFO steps down.- M&S launches 'M&S Man' social media campaign in menswear push.- WHSmith Board backs CEO amid accounting probe.- Lidl secures investor offer to fund construction of 35 stores across Europe.- Ahold Delhaize USA expands partnership with Instacart's FoodStorm platform.- Royal Mail and DHL suspend some US shipments.- Serbia caps food retail margins.- Lidl GB completes £435m UK warehouse investments.- Iceland rebrands its membership scheme.- Aldi added over 160 stores in Spain over the last 5 years.- Holland & Barrett appoints new CEO.- Co- op partners with Holland & Barrett.
UK Mid & Small Cap Leisure/Consumer NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European Food Retail  NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European General Retail  NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European Internet  POSITIVE  Unchanged
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 11. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 07:22 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 07:23 GMT Restricted - External

\\*\\*IN- PERSON\\*\\* Barclays 18th Annual Global Consumer Staples Conference (2- 4 September) The Barclays 18th Annual Global Consumer Staples Conference will be held at the InterContinental Boston. Anchored on presentations, fireside chats, and one- on- one meetings, the conference will feature a variety of Consumer Staples and Retail companies. The presenting speakers will include senior management from the following consumer segments: Food and Drug, Household & Personal Care, Beverages and Tobacco. European attendance: AAK, ABI, AD, BARN, BAYER, BEI, BAT, BN, CARLB, CPR, DGE, ESSITY, GIVN, GLB, HLN, HEIA, HEN3, IMB, JDEP, KYG, LINTD, NESN, NSISB, OR, PUIG, RI, RKT, RCO, SY1, TATE, ULVR.

\\*\\*IN- PERSON\\*\\* Jerónimo Martins Investor Trip in Warsaw (30 September) Please join us for a trip to Warsaw, Poland, where we will be hosting a meeting with the Biedronka CEO (1:00- 2:30pm) followed by a store tour (2:45- 4:00pm). This trip is convenient timing for those attending the Zabka Group investor event that is due to start that evening at 8:00pm in Warsaw.

\\*\\*SAVE THE DATE\\*\\* Barclays: European Retail Forum 2025 (7/14/21 November) Three days of virtual fireside chats with senior management from key European retailers including Ahold Delhaize, B&M, Carrefour, Dunelm, Greggs, H&M, JD Sports, Jerónimo Martins, M&S, NEXT, Pepco, Sainsbury, Tesco, Zabka, Zalando and 3i (Action). More companies will be added to the line- up. A detailed timetable will be released in September, but please 'save the date' in your calendar.

Carrefour CEO says French political crisis brings back recession risk. Carrefour CEO Alexandre Bompard said at a business conference yesterday that Prime Minister Francois Bayrou's decision to hold a confidence vote will weigh on consumer mood and could bring back recession fears, reported Yahoo Mail yesterday. Bompard said, "our morale is tied to the functioning of the state", adding "the more uncertainty there is, like it's the case right now, the higher the risk of a strong hit on the economy as consumers postpone their spending decisions".^

Carrefour Brasil CFO steps down. Carrefour Brasil announced yesterday that CFO Eric Alencar has resigned from his CFO, Investor Relations Officer, and President of the Board of Directors positions on a virtual meeting with the members of the Company's Board of Directors. CEO Pablo Lorenzo will now assume the role of Investor Relations Officer for Carrefour Brasil on an interim basis, until a permanent replacement is named, while Nelcina Tropardi has been elected as President of the Board of Directors. The CFO role will remain vacant until a replacement is chosen.^

EU to propose removing US tariffs this week. The European Union will reportedly seek to fast- track legislation to remove all tariffs on US industrial goods by the end of this week, reported Bloomberg yesterday. This is in response to a demand made by President Trump before the US will lower its duties on the EU's automobile exports. The European Commission will also give preferential rates on certain seafood and agricultural goods, according to people familiar with the matter. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen described it as "a strong, if not perfect deal".^

M&S launches 'M&S Man' social media campaign in menswear push. M&S announced yesterday that it will be launching M&S Man, an Instagram channel exclusively dedicated to men's style, as it is "mounting down on its ambition to broaden customer appeal". M&S will ramp up its menswear ambassador programme with content from Ian Wright, Vernon Kay, Olly Murs, and others. Mitch Hughes, Director of Menswear at M&S, said: "We are building our authority as a voice in men's style and doubling down on our ambition to become the go- to fashion brand for men. Hughes added: "we're introducing more style- led pieces, offering a wider choice every month, and investing more deeply in the right sizes and our best- selling lines."\*

WHSmith Board backs CEO amid accounting probe. WHSmith's board will stand by CEO Carl Cowling as it awaits the findings of the probe into its recent profit overstatement, reported the Financial Times this morning. Deloitte is investigating whether the error only relates to last year's accounts or whether profits in prior years may also have been overstated. Two people close to the company said Cowling has retained the board's backing at this stage.

Lidl secures investor offer to fund construction of 35 stores across Europe. Lidl has secured an offer from an investor to fund the construction of 35 stores across the UK and Europe in return for the freeholds, reported The Grocer yesterday. The portfolio includes 17 UK stores and 18 European stores and is under offer by investment group ICG for just over £250m. The proposal involves Lidl leasing the stores back once they are built. Lidl is aiming to complete the deal by the end of its financial year, in February 2026. Lidl did not comment on the details of the deal and ICG declined to comment.

Ahold Delhaize USA expands partnership with Instacart's FoodStorm platform. Ahold Delhaize USA has announced an expansion of its partnership with Instacart to leverage its FoodStorm order management system, reported Globe Newswire yesterday. The technology will enable participating Ahold Delhaize USA brands to elevate customers' shopping experience when requesting made- to- order items such as fresh bakery platters and customisable deli meat and cheese trays. The FoodStorm solution is live at Food Lion, GIANT, and MARTIN'S. Over time, Ahold Delhaize USA brands will evaluate the technology for further integration with and support of e- commerce capabilities like pre- ordering for pick- up or delivery.

Royal Mail and DHL suspend some US shipments. Royal Mail and DHL have halted shipments to the US over uncertainty around the upcoming scrapping of the 'de minimis' rule, reported Retail Gazette yesterday. Royal Mail said: "We have temporarily paused existing services to the USA from today (Tuesday 26 August 2025) while we put a new service in place." DHL stopped accepting business customer packages to the US on 23 August. Goods produced in the UK valued over £74.20 will incur a 10% tariff, following the UK- US trade deal on 8 May.

Serbia caps food retail margins. Serbia will limit retail and wholesale trade margins to a maximum of 20% and reduce commercial rebates to 10% on approximately 3,000 products across 23 product groups, reported European Supermarket Magazine yesterday. Serbian president Aleksandar Vučić announced the measures as part of a new package of economic reforms designed to improve the living standards of Serbian citizens and curb inflationary pressure. The new regulation will take effect on 1 September and remain in force for six months. The profit margin limits will primarily affect large retail chains, while smaller rural businesses will be exempt. The regulations will apply to the country's four largest retailers – Delhaize, Mercator- S, Lidl, and Univerexport – along with Aman, Gomez, BB Trade, Beltord, Ros Produkt, Veropoulos and Mikromarket. The measures will also extend to 13 smaller players, including Europrom, Leon, Konditor, Dufry, Senta Promet, Tekijanka, Metalac, Proleter, Fortuna Market, Šumadija Market, Cash&Carry Kula, Luki Komerc, and Vum.

Lidl GB completes £435m UK warehouse investments. Lidl has completed its two- stage extension at its London Belvedere site, investing £285m across two buildings, reported Retail Gazette yesterday. The first phase involved the construction of a new, second warehouse, equivalent to £160m, while the second stage saw the original building demolished to build a new state- of- the- art warehouse, which tripled capacity. The site now consists of a 800,000 sq ft warehouse space, or a +167% increase in its footprint since opening in 2003. In July, Lidl also started construction at its 38- acre site in Gildersome, Leeds, with a £150m investment.^

Iceland rebrands its membership scheme. Iceland has rebranded its Bonus Card membership scheme to the Iceland Bonus Club, and expanded its discounts and scale of rewards, as reported by Retail Gazette yesterday. To use the programme, customers need to preload designated amounts on to their loyalty account before redeeming them on in- store and online purchases. The frozen- food retailer will maintain its offer of granting members £1 back for every £20 spent with their Bonus Card, as well as gifting £5 to any new members who sign up before 1 September and granting its existing members with a £2 bonus if they boost their card amount to £20. The retailer has also increased the benefits of the scheme, including its new exclusive 'Bonus Club Rewards' which allows members to win rewards with a range of third- party vendors.^

Aldi added over 160 stores in Spain over the last 5 years. Aldi has added 168 new stores in the last 5 years in Spain, bringing its total store count to over 480 in the country, reported European Supermarket Magazine this morning. Since 2020, the discounter has entered new markets such as the Canary Islands, Melilla and Asturias, as well as strengthening its presence in key regions such as Catalonia, Andalusia, and Madrid. Aldi has also doubled its logistics capacity in Spain by opening three new distribution centres, and expanding three existing ones.

Holland & Barrett appoints new CEO. Holland & Barrett has appointed UK and Ireland CEO, Anthony Houghton, as its new Group CEO, Retail Week reported yesterday. He will take on the role from October when H&B's new financial year begins. Houghton has been with the retailer since September 2018 as group retail and property director, then as COO, and is currently CEO of the UK and Ireland business. Holland & Barrett has also appointed Vineta Bajaj as the new group CFO, with previous experience across markets and Ocado Group.^

Co- op partners with Holland & Barrett. Co- op has agreed a partnership with Holland & Barrett (H&B) to grow the health and wellness offer across its convenience stores, reported NamNews yesterday. From this week, a new H&B range alongside emerging brands will appear in 125 Co- op stores. The branded 'Health and Wellness' bays will consist of 52 lines, including vitamins and supplements, which focus on gut health, family wellbeing and preventative health from H&B, Symprove and Zooki.^

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: We value Carrefour by taking an average of the valuations generated by a DCF and a 'sum- of- the- parts'. 'DCF. We use a common DCF methodology for all our companies (formulaic fade rates, capex fading towards depreciation, etc). The two key inputs - apart from WACC, which is necessarily somewhat subjective - are for the terminal margin and growth rates. For Carrefour we assume a terminal EBIT margin of \(3.4\%\) , slightly up compared with the level we forecast in 2027E. We think this is realistic given the structural constraints on the company's margins (formats, real estate, franchises). We assume \(1.5\%\) terminal sales growth, which is at the lower end of the \(1.0 - 2.5\%\) range that we use for companies in the sector - reflecting its exposure to a mix of mature European markets and developing markets. 'Sum- of- the- parts. We apply different EV/sales multiples on the various segments, reflecting their expected profit margins and growth rates. We are most generous with the French convenience business ( \(35\%\) ), Spain ( \(35\%\) ) and Brazil ( \(35\%\) ) and most cautious with French hypermarkets ( \(22\%\) ). Both methodologies generate a value of approximately €15.75 and we use this as our price target.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The three main risks we see to our Overweight rating on Carrefour are as follows: 1) Competitive risk - the possibility that competition steps back up in France. 2) FX risk - especially in relation to the Brazilian and Argentine currencies against the euro. 3) Macro backdrop - the possibility that consumer spending remains depressed in Carrefour's key markets of France, Spain and Brazil.
Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHT  Industry View: NEUTRAL  Closing Price: GBP 3.52 (27- Aug- 2025)
Rating and Price Target Chart - GBP (as of 27- Aug- 2025)  Currency=GBP
Source: IDC, Barclays Research  Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting
On 28-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 2.15.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value M&S based on a combination of a DCF and a sum-of-the-parts model. Our key assumptions in the DCF are as follows: 1) terminal sales growth of 2.0%; 2) a WACC of 9.0%; 3) a terminal margin of 8.0%. In our SOTP, we use FY27E EBITDA multiples: 7.3x for Food,6.0x for Clothing & Home and 8.0x for International.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** We believe the major risks to our M&S investment case are the following: 1) Although the 'cost-of-living' crisis in the UK has not seemed to affect M&S's performance so far, rising mortgage costs could still bite at some point. 2) Cash exceptional charges may remain elevated for an extended period of time. 3) The M&S Clothing & Home business has benefited from a shift away from discounting, and this may reverse at some point when availability of stock returns closer to normal (or if weather is unhelpful for an extended period).

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate-friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
